newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Dragonair plane makes emergency landing near Manila.
newsitem.headline: Dragonair plane makes emergency landing near Manila.

text.p: A Hong Kong Dragon Airlines (Dragonair) Airbus 330 made an emergency landing at Subic Bay in the Philippines on Friday, airport officials said -- the latest incident involving Rolls-Royce Plc engines.

Flight KA-MH061 from Hong Kong landed safely at Subic Bay international airport after developing engine trouble en route to Kota Kinabalu in Malaysia, Rene Paguia, official-in-charge of the airport, told Reuters.
Air traffic controllers said the Dragonair pilot landed using only one engine.
"We were told by the pilot that the plane's left engine conked out," an air traffic controller told Reuters.
None of the 127 passengers and crew was hurt, airport officials said.
A Dragonair spokeswoman in Hong Kong said the Airbus 330-300 was fitted with two Rolls-Royce Trent 700 engines and made an unscheduled stop at the Subic Bay airport "because of the engine".
Problems with gearbox bearings in Trent 700 engines have forced Hong Kong flag carrier Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd Airbus 330-300s to make a series of unscheduled single-engine landings recently.

A Cathay Pacific plane with Trent 700 engines made a single-engine landing at Bangkok last week. Two weeks ago a flight to the Philippines had return to Hong Kong, a Cathay Pacific spokesman told Reuters in Hong Kong on Wednesday.
A Vietnam-bound Cathay airliner had to make a single-engine landing last November, he added.
In April, a Dragonair airliner suffered a similar gearbox problem while flying from Hong Kong to Shanghai, Hong Kong's South China Morning Post newspaper said on Wednesday.
Cathay operates 11 A330-300s using Trent 700 engines, while its sister airline Dragonair uses four.
Indonesian airline Garuda operates five of the planes.
Rolls-Royce said on Thursday it believed it had found a design solution to the gearbox problem.
